Health, Nutrition and Population m1327755 621,Essential Package of Health Services

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the Health
            Sector Support Project for Guinea was judged to be
            moderately satisfactory.  The Bank and borrower performance
            were moderately satisfactory. The risk to development
            outcome was high. Significant changes included restructuring
            of the project, and amending the Development Credit
            Agreement to: (i) eliminate counterpart financing  and
            reallocate the proceeds; and (ii) revise the closing date of
            the project.  Several lessons were learned. Project design
            must balance a range of considerations. These include the
            desired outcomes, the financing instrument, and the
            implementation arrangements. Risk assessment is an essential
            aspect of project design. While overall risk was rated as
            high, the components of this rating were underestimated and
            the mitigation measures were insufficient. Where ministry
            leadership is inadequate, other champions must be found to
            advance the project's objectives. The Bank's
            comparative advantages need to be recognized and exploited.
            There is a need to temper expectations that a single health
            project can impact the entire health sector. While a single
            project financed by the Bank may be a necessary condition
            for sectoral change, it is not sufficient without greater
            political leadership and financial commitment from the
            Guinean authorities. Monitoring and evaluation (M&E) can
            be improved throughout the project. Though the general
            prescription is that M&E systems, including arrangements
            for collecting and analyzing data, should be established
            prior to project launch, Guinea shows that projects can
            recover from inadequate M&E design and early
            implementation weaknesses.
